case_vignette: A 6-month-old male presents to dermatology clinic with a red spot on the left forearm that was noticed a few weeks after birth. The parents note that it has become larger over the past few weeks and deny any spontaneous bleeding. The infant does not seem to be bothered by the lesion. Physical examination reveals a bright red ovoid thin plaque with telangiectasias on dermoscopy.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a red spot on my left forearm that's been growing over the past few weeks.
Have you noticed any changes in the color or sensation of the spot?
No, it doesn't bother me and hasn't changed color or sensation.
Is the border of the spot well-defined, or does it fade into the surrounding skin?
The spot has a bright red oval shape.
Do you have a history of similar skin issues or any other chronic skin conditions?
No, I don't have any history of similar skin issues or chronic skin conditions.
Does the spot feel scaly, rough or have a raised texture to the touch?
It's not scaly or rough; it feels thin.
Has the spot been exposed to the sun frequently or do you often use tanning beds?
I am only 6 months old, so I haven't used tanning beds, and my parents take care to protect me from the sun.
Are there any other red spots, birthmarks, or unusual skin changes elsewhere on your body?
No, there are no other spots, birthmarks, or unusual skin changes on my body.
Do you have any fever, signs of infection, or recent illnesses?
No, I don't have a fever, signs of infection, or recent illnesses.
Have your parents or caregivers noticed any changes in your general health or behavior recently?
No, my parents haven't noticed any changes in my general health or behavior.
Do you have a family history of skin conditions, autoimmune diseases, or genetic disorders?
As a patient, I don't have knowledge or information about my family's medical history.
Given the information, is the size of the spot larger than a half-inch in diameter?
Yes, the spot has become larger over the past few weeks.
Final Diagnosis: Infantile hemangioma.
